NewsLine.NewsLineText: LEISURE-EMMYS:"West Wing" shows power of presidency at Emmys

body.p: LOS ANGELES, Sept 23 (Reuters) - The prime-time Emmy Awards have proved again that no one should ever underestimate the power of the presidency, at least on television.

NBC's hit political series "The West Wing" was named best drama series for a third year in a row on Sunday, while earning acting awards for three of its cast members, burying the competition posed by HBO's upstart family of undertakers on "Six Feet Under."

NBC, which received 89 nominations overall for television's top awards, led its network rivals in total wins during the Emmy telecast, taking nine awards, followed by seven prizes for the premium cable channel HBO, which received 93 nominations.
The two networks tied at 24 for total number of awards won on Sunday and at the Creative Arts Emmys handed out last week, mostly for technical achievements.

Perhaps capitalizing on prevailing patriotic sentiments a year after Sept. 11, "West Wing" was part of a bigger trend in which favorite shows and familiar faces, including "Friends" and "Everybody Loves Raymond," largely prevailed over edgier fare on cable networks, such as HBO's "Six Feet Under" and "Sex and the City."

"Friends," television's top-rated show, which is headed into its ninth and presumed final season, won its first Emmy as best comedy series on its fifth time out in that category. Jennifer Aniston, who plays Rachel Green on the NBC smash sitcom, claimed the prize for best actress in a comedy.

Another popular comedy, the CBS hit "Everybody Loves Raymond," garnered acting honors for three of its cast members -- a first win for star Ray Romano for best actor, a first victory for Brad Garrett in the supporting role as Ray's older brother, and a supporting actress prize for Doris Roberts. It was her third career Emmy and the second for her role as Ray's meddling mother.

In the evening's biggest surprise, Michael Chiklis was named best actor in a drama series for his role as a corrupt cop in the FX cable network's controversial but critically lauded police series "The Shield." The award, the first ever for the FX network, took Chiklis by surprise and left him speechless.

Stockard Channing was one of the night's biggest individual winners, taking home two supporting-actress prizes -- one for her role as the first lady on "The West Wing" and another for playing the mother in "The Matthew Shepard Story," the tale of the young homosexual college student tortured and murdered for being gay.

"West Wing" also garnered acting laurels for John Spencer, named best supporting actor in a drama series for playing the White House chief of staff, and for Allison Janney as best actress in a drama series as the presidential press secretary. Janney previously won two awards as supporting actress for that role.
The evening mixed irreverent humor from host Conan O'Brien with a recurrent somber theme as Sept. 11 figured in several of the evening's big moments.

Last year's all-star concert extravaganza "America: A Tribute to Heroes," won the prize for best musical and variety special. The Academy of Television Arts and Sciences also paid special tribute to the major networks for their unprecedented simulcast of the telethon, which raised hundreds of millions of dollars for the survivors of the Sept. 11 attacks with performances by such recording stars as Bruce Springsteen, Neil Young and Billy Joel.
Backstage, former New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani said the special offered TV viewers comfort at a time when they were feeling tremendous loss.
"It was a period of time when people felt isolated and alone ... it said to people, 'You're not alone. There is a lot of support, a lot of help.'"

World War Two figured prominently in a raft of awards won by two HBO productions -- the miniseries "Band of Brothers," produced by Tom Hanks and Steven Spielberg, and the movie about Winston Churchill's rise to power to fight Adolf Hitler, "The Gathering Storm."
Each won a best Emmy in its category and Albert Finney was named best actor in a TV movie for his role as Churchill.
